Situation1: They review project timelines casually, ensuring tasks are generally progressing.
Expectation2: Recite and reflect on the Quran
Situation2: Ramadan’s midpoint arrives and the daily reading quota is slightly behind.
Story: I sat at my desk, blueprints spread out before me, the hum of the office fading into the background as I glanced at the clock. The project timeline was tight, but I’d been reviewing tasks with a casual eye, trusting my team to keep things moving. Still, a nagging worry crept in—deadlines loomed, and I was expected to manage every detail efficiently. My phone buzzed with a reminder: it was time for my daily Quran reading. Ramadan was halfway through, and I was already behind on my reading quota. The expectation to recite and reflect weighed heavily on me, especially now, when every moment felt precious. I stared at the open blueprint, my mind drifting to the verses I hadn’t yet read. Guilt pressed in from both sides—my faith urging me to pause and reconnect, my profession demanding focus and control. I closed my eyes, feeling the tension coil in my chest, torn between the demands of my work and the spiritual nourishment I craved.
